titleStmt.title: The Famous Whore, or Noble Curtizan
titleStmt.author: Garvase Markham

publicationStmt.publisher: Collaboratory for Writing and Research on Culture (CWRC https://cwrc.ca) and Linked Editing Academic Framework (LEAF https://leaf-vre.org).

sourceDesc.p: This TEI document was adapted from the template created by members of CWRC and LEAF using pedagogical materials from Laura Estill and Rebecca Nesvet.

monogr.author: Garvase Markham
monogr.title: The Famous Whore, or Noble Curtizan: conteining the lamentable complaint of Paulina, the famous Roman curtizan, sometimes mes. unto the grreat cardinall Hypolito, of Est.

imprint.pubPlace: and are to be sold at shop by the great South gate of Paules.

msIdentifier.repository: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

projectDesc.p: This template was made available for use with the LEAF-Writer semantic editor. It was adapted by Andie Silva and the York College ENG 328 Fall 2025 class.

normalization.p: Original spelling maintained with alternate options for modern spelling using the choice, orig and reg elements. Capitalization of nouns has been silently removed/maintained.

hyphenation.p: End-of-line hyphenation silently removed where appropriate

revisionDesc.change: Revised blank template for use with LEAF-Writer editor.
Adapted template for using with York College ENG 328 class.
Added transcriptions and first pass at encoding.
Final proofing and editing for publication.

p.hi:
entlemen, I hauehave aduentured adventured to bring a whore into your company, but with no bad intent, but to give you honest Recreation, not to hurt you in purse or body: Therefore you must thinke think this is a famous strange whore: for shee she
seekes seeks the hurt of no man. Wrong her not then, but giuegive her kind welcome out of Italy: for she hath had bin been a meeremere stranger to our English nation till this howre hour . And yet Gentlemen you know some of her kindred: Therefore loue love her, for their sakes whom you loue love , and let us shewshow our seluesselves as courteous as Italians, and except accept her kindly,
